title: Why US retailers are failing to crack the British high street
text:
When US fashion chain Forever 21 threw open the doors to its first UK store on Oxford Street eight years ago, a queue of 500 shoppers had been waiting outside for three hours in anticipation.

Eager young customers were handed goody bags, ice cream and sweets before the shop, which was home to HMV's first store in 1921, opened to the public at 10am.

Fast forward to 2019 and Forever 21’s dreams of cracking the fiercely competitive UK fashion market lie in tatters.

The retailer revealed this week it will shut 178 shops worldwide after filing for bankruptcy protection in the US, leaving its three UK stores in London, Liverpool and Birmingham at risk of closure.

Clive Black, head of research at...
